Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing a wide range of physical phenomena. However, its foundations have been a matter of debate for more than a century. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. Our results show that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is equivalent to the category of measurable spaces and measurable functions. This result is a step toward a categorical approach to quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the bare minimum required for survival as a parasitic organism. This reduction is accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. Our findings suggest that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the cnidarians. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields. This study quantifies the magnitude of this increase and its consequences for global food security. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Herbivores are essential components of ecosystems, but their impacts on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are poorly understood. One reason for this is that we lack a comprehensive understanding of how herbivores partition food resources. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in body size and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Our findings also highlight the importance of species-level diet analyses for understanding the impacts of herbivores on ecosystems. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the survey also reveals substantial uncertainty about the length of the crisis. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. We also find that many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans. However, we also find that many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a major environmental concern. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected. This is mainly due to size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950. This expansion has been driven by the motorized fleet, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most numerous and the most important in terms of engine power. The powered-artisanal fleet has been expanding rapidly in developing countries, where it is expected to continue to grow. The powered-artisanal fleet has been responsible for the decline in effective catch per unit of effort. The effective CPUE of most countries has been reduced by more than 50% since 1950. The powered-artisanal fleet is a major contributor to overfishing. The powered-artisanal fleet is expected to continue to expand, but the rate of expansion is slowing.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of life. In placental mammals, the mother’s ability to reproduce is limited by her own metabolic power. This is because the mother must provide all of the energy required to support the developing offspring. We show that the ability to provide energy to the offspring is a strong determinant of reproductive output. We also show that the ability to provide energy to the offspring is correlated with domestication and all forms of allocare. This suggests that the ability to provide energy to the offspring is a general mechanism for increasing reproductive output. This mechanism may be important for understanding the evolution of placental mammals. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. The endothelium controls vascular function and is the first line of defense against infection and injury. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to specific stimuli. The endothelium is organized into clusters of cells that communicate with each other to control vascular function. The communication system between cells is poorly understood. Here, we use single-cell Ca2+ imaging to determine the nature of the communication system between endothelial cells. We find that the communication system is a scale-free network with short path lengths. The network is particularly dynamic and efficient. The findings provide insight into the nature of the communication system between endothelial cells and the control of vascular function. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this Threonine residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We also show that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the K+ channel family. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health. The gut microbiome is also highly dynamic and can be altered by the host and environmental factors. The gut microbiome is also a reservoir for antibiotic-resistant bacteria. The gut microbiome is therefore an important target for the development of new therapeutics. The gut microbiome is also a potential source of new natural products. Here, we show that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize natural products that could be harnessed as a source of therapeutics. This study provides a foundation for the discovery of new natural products from anaerobic gut fungi. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders and is associated with impaired social behavior. Here we show that anxiety influences social dominance in rats and identify an important role for brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter exhibit reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that this low mitochondrial function is a cause and effect of the subordinate status. Finally, we demonstrate that the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety is reversed by pharmacological interventions that restore mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a critical issue for the development of mechanical systems. However, the design of complex structures with specific behaviors is challenging due to the restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple hyperelastic materials. The structures are digitally synthesized with organic shapes and motions. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This article is protected by copyright. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is heterochronous, with fetal hemoglobin (HbF) being expressed at high levels and adult hemoglobin (HbA) at low levels. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of this heterochronous pattern. IGF2BP1 is downregulated in human erythroblasts and mediates a developmental silencing of HbF and an upregulation of HbA. This mechanism may be important for the development of fetal hemoglobin in humans. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. Cancer is a major cause of death worldwide. Cancer cells are characterized by uncontrolled proliferation and resistance to apoptosis. In this study, we found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway are resistant to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis. Conversely, cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway are sensitive to ferroptosis induction. We also found that ferroptosis induction in cancer cells sensitizes them to chemotherapy. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a useful therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. In addition, the combination of ferroptosis induction and PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway inhibition may be a promising approach for cancer treatment. Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. The underlying mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are complex and not fully understood. Here, we show that the major class of antihypertensive drugs, voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel blockers, promote vascular remodeling through activation of store-operated Ca2+ entry. Our findings suggest that the use of these drugs should be limited in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for biodiversity conservation in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated adaptive management, and was the first to require monitoring of biodiversity. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test the influence of the NWFP on biodiversity. Our results show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral bird populations, but failed to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated species. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of older forests, and the proportion of older forests declined. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of early-seral bird populations, and the proportion of early-seral ecosystems increased. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a rational design strategy for the discovery of new antibiotics. We use computational predictions of membrane permeability, binding affinity to the ribosome, and solubility to screen a library of acylide antibiotics. We show that the best candidate is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The best compounds designed by us show activity against three of the most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy is applicable to other antibiotic classes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices before bedtime has become ubiquitous. This study shows that this practice can have important consequences for sleep. Participants who read an electronic book before bedtime took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell activation. Its function in the development of autoimmunity is well established, but its role in the development of tolerance is less clear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of tolerance to self-antigens. We also show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of tolerance to self-antigens in the absence of the development of autoimmunity. This is important because congenital CTLA-4 deficiency is lethal. Our findings have implications for the development of tolerance in different diseases. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We found that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. These novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that beetles diversified due to low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines and therapies. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning algorithm to enhance the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our algorithm can be used to optimize antibody sequences to improve binding affinity against multiple variants. We applied our algorithm to a human antibody, P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We demonstrated that our algorithm can improve the antibody’s potency against Delta by ∼10- to 600-fold. Our results suggest that our algorithm can be used to engineer antibodies for the current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work provides a new approach for antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is the process by which cultural traits spread through a population and become more common over time. The extent to which larger populations enhance CCE is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment in which we manipulated population size and investigated the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances). We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE. This finding is important because it suggests that CCE may be more limited than previously thought.

The apoE allele is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE is a major component of the classical complement cascade and its presence in the brain increases the risk of AD by ∼12-fold. The role of APOE in AD pathogenesis is not yet clear. Here we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the only solid sphere in the solar system. The inner core is a mystery because it is difficult to form. The most popular theory is that the inner core formed by the solidification of the outer core. However, this theory is not supported by the fact that the outer core is liquid. We show that the inner core formed by the nucleation of iron crystals. This mechanism explains the mystery of the inner core.

Marijuana legalization debates highlight the need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use. Here, we show that marijuana abusers have reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers show reduced decreases in striatal dopamine D2 receptor availability (reflecting DA increases) when challenged with MP. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that marijuana abusers have decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. Language is the defining feature of humanity. Yet, despite its importance, the neural mechanisms of language comprehension remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also predict neural responses to sentences in humans. This suggests that the mechanisms of language comprehension in these networks are also relevant to the human brain. We discuss the implications of these results for our understanding of language and the human mind. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is still unclear how to design stable DL algorithms. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) but there is no algorithm that can compute such a NN. This is a fundamental paradox. We resolve this paradox by introducing a classification theory of stability. We also introduce a fast iterative restarted network algorithm that is stable and converges quadratically fast.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors. One of the most prominent is the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This is supposedly shown by a classic experiment published 45 years ago. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not noticed at the time. They are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. The disease is characterized by progressive loss of sensation and disfigurement. The pathogen has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and the genome sequence of the only known species, Mycobacterium leprae, is available. We sequenced the genome of a new species, M. lepromatosis, which causes a different clinical condition, diffuse lepromatous leprosy. The two species are closely related and have retained many functions required to infect the peripheral nervous system. The two species also share the ability to cause a reactional condition known as Lucio’s phenomenon. Our findings suggest that the two species have retained the ability to cause disease for millions of years. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. The study of their interplay is a central topic in quantum information theory and statistical physics. In this work, we unveil the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of a quantum quench in the one-dimensional Heisenberg model. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. Our result is exact and holds in the scaling limit of infinite system length and large system size. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg model.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors. We developed a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine protects hamsters from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. The vaccine is highly attenuated, and the protective dose is a single intranasal dose. This makes the vaccine suitable for mass vaccination programs.

The Black Death caused a major population decline in Europe and led to the Second Pandemic of plague. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic in comparative neurobiology. However, it is biased by the fact that brain size is often used as a proxy for brain power. Here, we show that this is not the case. We use the largest dataset of its kind to show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This bias in the comparison of brain evolution across amniotes has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results also suggest that the evolution of brain power is not only a matter of increasing brain size but also of increasing the number of neurons. This is important for understanding the evolution of the human brain. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, its function in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. This study provides a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is essential for cell migration, cell division, and cytokinesis. ADF is also involved in the formation of stress fibers and lamellipodia. The ADF/cofilin complex is the only known ADF/cofilin complex that can sever actin filaments. However, how it does so is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin can sever filaments under mechanical stress. We propose a mechanochemical model that explains our results. This model suggests that ADF/cofilin can sever highly connected filament networks far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. This finding is important for understanding the function of ADF/cofilin in cells. It may also have implications for the design of new actin depolymerizing factor/cofilin inhibitors. Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is widely used in the United States. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and food-seeking behavior are unknown. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. This may be particularly relevant in light of the fact that fructose is often consumed in the absence of satiety. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and its associated comorbidities. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean with a rich cultural and genetic heritage. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous. We also find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a reference for future studies on the human history of the Indian Ocean region. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We are influenced by the emotions of others. This influence can be transferred from one person to another, even when they are not in direct contact. We show that this influence can be observed in a large social network, Facebook. We show that people’s own emotional states are influenced by the emotional content of others’ posts. This work suggests that people do not need to be in direct contact with others to be influenced by their emotions. This work also suggests that people can be influenced by the positive experiences of others.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not only protein-coding, but also include nonprotein-coding RNA sequences. One of the most common modifications in mRNA coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is present in 10–20% of mRNA nucleotides. We show that the presence of Ψ can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our findings suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA sequences and that this can have consequences for protein synthesis. Our work also highlights the importance of mRNA modifications in directing protein synthesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age. These associations are robust to adjustment for a range of sociodemographic and health-related factors. Longitudinal analyses indicate that higher worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes. These findings suggest that the feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in evolutionary biology. The aquatic lifestyle is known to be associated with larger body sizes, but the extent to which this is driven by ecological, biomechanical, or physiological factors remains unclear. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to test the hypothesis that the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in mammals. We find that the aquatic lifestyle is indeed driving the evolution of larger body sizes in mammals. This finding is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium. Our results have implications for the evolution of body size in other taxa and for the design of aquatic habitats. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The common cold is a major cause of school absenteeism and lost work productivity. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication suggests that cold symptoms are caused by rhinovirus infection. However, the mechanism by which rhinovirus replicates preferentially at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity is unknown. We show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more efficient antiviral defense response at 37 °C than at 33 °C. This difference in the magnitude of the antiviral response accounts for the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication. Our findings suggest that the cold temperature of the nasal cavity may be an important factor in the pathogenesis of the common cold. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to sense surfaces. The pili-mediated surface sensing system is required for long-term attachment to surfaces and for the regulation of virulence. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing provides a mechanism for how bacteria can use pili for sensing and motility. This work also demonstrates that type IV pili can be used for sensing surfaces on short timescales. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing may be applicable to other bacteria. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. The virus has also infected many animals, including white-tailed deer, which are susceptible to infection. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem. The impacts of these dams are well documented, but the industry continues to build them. This paper examines the causes of the problem and proposes solutions. The paper also examines the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder with no known cure. The disease is associated with the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. The exact mechanisms by which these proteins cause neuronal death are not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons are capable of producing inflammatory factors that can trigger microglial activation. This neuron-derived inflammatory response may be a significant contributor to AD pathogenesis. Our findings suggest that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant factor in the development of AD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species. However, its history is still largely unknown. The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. We present evidence from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, that economic exploitation of chickens was practiced in the fourth century B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for economic exploitation of chickens. Our results are supported by a survey of chicken remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of the domestic chicken. It also has implications for the history of animal domestication and the spread of agriculture. (Read more)

The folding of large proteins is a major unsolved problem in biophysics. We have developed a method to study folding at high structural resolution. The method is based on the use of hydrogen exchange to probe the structure of the folded state and to monitor the folding process. We have applied the method to study the folding of maltose binding protein. The results show that the folding process of large proteins is more complex than previously thought. Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is inactivated by stress, preferentially decapsulates Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that arginine deprivation could be involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We demonstrated that arginine deprivation is associated with the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells. We also showed that arginine deprivation is associated with a decrease in T cell proliferation and mitogen-induced lymphocyte activation. We found that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and physics where a system can self-regulate its activity level. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity levels. The sandpile model is the archetypical SOC system. In this paper, we show that the sandpile model has a continuous scaling limit, which is a certain scaling limit of the tropical sandpile model. We discuss the implications of our result for the theory of SOC.

Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly under strain. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of intersexual communication. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We used proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. These female-derived proteins support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied extensively. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The database is freely available to the scientific community.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL can measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI. The observations show that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense debate for decades. The most widely accepted temperature estimate is 15 °C today, but this value is based on isotopic evidence that has been subject to question. Here, we use the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to determine the temperature of Earth’s surface in the past. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface cooled from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean to the present 15 °C. This finding is consistent with both isotopic and protein reconstruction-based estimates. We believe that integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data holds promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are important for ion flow and cell signaling. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels can exhibit slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We propose that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that BK channel C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent. Our findings may help us understand the BK channel’s unique properties and may provide insights into the pathophysiology of the disease. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the red blood cell (RBC). Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane to facilitate entry. We show that the malaria parasite binds to glycophorin A on the RBC membrane and that this binding alters the RBC membrane’s biophysical properties. These changes in the RBC membrane are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC membrane, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This work provides a new perspective on malaria parasite invasion and opens up new avenues for the development of new antimalarial drugs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Diamond is a promising material for quantum applications. However, its electronic properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for quantum applications.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The impact of environmental factors on influenza virus transmission and host response to infection remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice lacking caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in host defense against influenza virus infection. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of environmental factors on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to be based on a tree-like structure of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures remains largely unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only capture activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. Axin is a key component of the pathway that converts signals at the plasma membrane to signals inhibiting the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key regulator of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the lateral hypothalamus. Lesions of this circuit prevent eating induced by LH stimulation. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle. The ability of plants to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in their root microbiome is a key component of the plant-symbiont interaction. Here, we demonstrate the control of nitrogen fixation in a model plant–bacterial system using a synthetic signaling pathway. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signaling molecule. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. The Amazon is losing forest cover at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and respond to deforestation. However, the effectiveness of these systems in deterring deforestation is unclear. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities. However, the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Animals use their hearing to detect and localize acoustic signals, which are important for survival. The hearing organs of animals are constrained by the body size of animals. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. The spider’s web is flexible and can be regenerated after damage. The outsourcing and supersizing of hearing in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a global phaseout of fossil fuels and major anthropogenic sources of air pollution. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuels can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. The chemical influence of air pollution on dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing pollution particles liberates 0.73 °C warming. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results show that the health benefits of climate mitigation are much larger than previously thought. This study is the first to quantify the health benefits of a global phaseout of fossil fuels and major anthropogenic sources of air pollution. It provides a framework for a global assessment of the health benefits of climate mitigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. Vaccine development efforts have been accelerated, and several vaccines are now available. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. We report an engineered SARS-CoV-2 RBD that exhibits high-yield manufacturability, high-affinity binding to ACE2, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 RBD used in current vaccines. This engineered RBD can be presented on a designed VLP, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD may provide a cost-effective and accessible vaccine for global access. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor in infants. The majority of neuroblastoma cases is sporadic, but a small fraction is inherited. The molecular basis of the inherited disease is unknown. Here we show that mutations in anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) are associated with a subset of familial neuroblastoma. We also show that secreted small ALKAL proteins (FAM150s) are ligands for human ALK and that zebrafish ALKALs activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK. Our results provide evidence that FAM150s are ligands for ALK and suggest that FAM150s and ALK may be involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has caused devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of reconstructed genomes from this period is too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in predicting support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election. Copyright © 2021. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on the North American Great Plains remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated SOC in the top 15 cm of soil. These practices also enhanced soil microbial biomass and C-use efficiency but did not increase particulate organic carbon. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC on North American agricultural soils. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive approach to identifying and prioritizing viral threats to human health. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with spillover and spread of viruses from animals to humans. We then used this framework to systematically rank the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking system can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a framework for systematically identifying and prioritizing viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the reward’s nutritional value. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We demonstrate that this alkaloid is attractive to a vertebrate pollinator. This work provides evidence that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait in two different plant families. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from southern Germany dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. The emergence of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) in humans has caused ∼36% fatality. The bat origin of MERS-CoV suggests that bats are the natural reservoir of the virus. To understand how these bat coronaviruses can cause disease in humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the bat coronaviruses are different from those of MERS-CoV. These results suggest that the bat coronaviruses have adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. This study provides insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the risk of bat coronaviruses to human health. Copyright © 2017. Published by Elsevier Inc.

We describe a large-scale, resource-scarce setting mNGS study of undifferentiated febrile illness. Our findings suggest that mNGS can be used to identify the regional pathogen landscape and surveillance of emerging pathogens in resource-scarce settings. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. The origin of life is a central problem in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA polymerase ribozymes can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. In this paper, we describe an improved RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase ribozyme can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the in vitro evolution of RNA-based life. (Read more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. We found that the patients with severe or critical COVID-19 have high levels of proinflammatory cytokines and immune cells. Tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can reduce the levels of proinflammatory cytokines and immune cells. It can also improve the clinical symptoms and reduce mortality. Therefore, tocilizumab is a promising treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but excess copper is toxic. The maintenance of copper homeostasis is a complex process in which fungi employ a variety of mechanisms. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and impacts cellular copper content. We demonstrate that xanthocillin-derived isocyanide metabolites have antimicrobial properties and are secreted by A. fumigatus. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study highlights the importance of natural products in fungal metal homeostasis and the potential for these compounds to be exploited for therapeutic purposes. The formation of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is rare. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph. The sedimentary environment is also significant because it is a potential source of the tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in the rock. The sedimentary environment is also consistent with the formation of the amorphous silica, which is the dominant X-ray amorphous material in the rock. The sedimentary environment is also consistent with the diagenesis of the primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products. The diagenesis products are the mixed-cation salts and oxides and possibly the crystalline magnetite. The diagenesis products are post lithification fracture/vein fill. The diagenesis products are consistent with the variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities of multiple aqueous solutions. The diagenesis products are also consistent with the presence of a “Lake Gale” catchment environment.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant growth and productivity, and its impact is expected to increase in a warming world. However, the geographic distribution of frost risk is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly associated with the evolutionary history of the species. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of the development of Th1-like cells from Th17 precursors is unknown. Here we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. This dual mechanism of action is critical for the development of colitis. These results have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

This study provides evidence that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. (Read more)

Suspension rates are rising in the United States. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This change in mindset is associated with a reduction in suspensions. The intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the O2-EtdT lesion is recognized by pol II as a normal DNA template. In contrast, the N3-EtdT lesion is recognized as a normal DNA template only after proofreading activity is stimulated by TFIIS. The O4-EtdT lesion is recognized by pol II as a normal DNA template but leads to a dominant error-prone route. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these emissions. Increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering outlets could have a significant impact on reducing these emissions. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering outlet can lead to a proportional increase in sales. This suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a simple and effective way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. This approach could be used to reduce the environmental impact of the food system more generally.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space. We apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to millions of infections and thousands of deaths. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune system, but the molecular mechanisms underlying this evasion are unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8. We show that SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 can form a unique large-scale assembly, which may be involved in immune suppression and evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic. (Read more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. The problem of selective inference is that we have cherry-picked a dataset and we must set a higher bar for declaring significant associations. This paper describes some recent developments in selective inference. We illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires multiple transcription factors. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs and the development of vascular regeneration. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 may be a useful tool for the study of human EC development. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we show that the zebrafish orthologs of these ligands, augmentor, are essential for pigment development. We also show that augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of photoreceptor that is unique to the adult zebrafish. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentor ligands are required for the development of iridophores in a tissue-specific context. This work provides insight into the function of these orphan RTKs in vivo and may lead to the identification of new therapeutic targets for cancer and other diseases. β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Herein, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, STING-βKO β-cells exhibited defective GSIS and loss of nuclear translocation of Pax6. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual seasonal epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging of the viral genome is essential for the production of infectious virions. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication. We show that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the development of cardiovascular diseases. The atheroprone flow environment is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms underlying the atheroprone flow regulation of vascular cells are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a key event in the flow regulation of vascular cells. Our results suggest that the activation of YAP/TAZ is a critical mechanism for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. This increase has led to substantial economic and ecological costs. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Our results suggest that actions to reduce human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus that causes microcephaly and other neurological complications in newborns. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the within-host dynamics of ZIKV are consistent with the clinical observations of the disease. We also show that an antiviral treatment can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can inform the design of future clinical trials of antiviral drugs.
