Coral bleaching is a major stressor of coral reefs worldwide. The underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. We show that altered nutrient cycling during heat stress is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. Heat stress increased the metabolic energy demand of the coral host, which was compensated by the catabolic degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promoted the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Energy limitation and altered symbiotic nutrient cycling are thus key factors in the early heat stress response, directly contributing to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Interpreting the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the absence of a tumor, the epithelium maintains tight barrier function and is colonized by a diverse microbiome. Here, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the microbiome and trigger a regenerative response that promotes tumor growth. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome can restore intestinal barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also suggest that targeting JNK signaling may be a promising strategy to treat intestinal tumors and restore intestinal homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The development of breast cancer is associated with chemotherapy, which may select for cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increases in breast cancer cells following chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with the eruption of Mount Takahe, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion. This unique volcanic event is associated with a unique, ∼192-y series of halogens in ice cores, which plausibly links the Mount Takahe eruptions to the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. This study demonstrates that volcanic eruptions can have a significant impact on climate and that volcanic records can be used to test climate models. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries catches, which reveal that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of river ecosystems and to assess the impacts of fisheries on food security. Our findings highlight the importance of freshwater fisheries for food security and biodiversity conservation.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is limited by the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The adult mammalian nervous system is incapable of regenerating after injury. This inability is due to the loss of the ability to regenerate in the adult CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling cascade. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the sensory dendrite or mutations disrupting sensory activity, calcium signaling, or genes that restrict outgrowth during neuronal maturation. These connections suggest that ectopic outgrowth represents a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between this form of outgrowth and lesion conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of outgrowth to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This study also provides a model for studying the molecular mechanisms of regeneration in the adult CNS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Recombination is essential for genome integrity and the maintenance of genetic diversity. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to DNA sequences. In humans and mice, these binding sites are defined by the positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9 (PRDM9). In plants, the corresponding protein is unknown. We use a population of wild monkeyflowers to map the locations of PRDM9 binding sites. We find that the binding sites are not randomly distributed across the genome, but rather are clustered in hotspots of recombination. These results suggest that the binding sites are not the only conserved elements of PRDM9 function. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Resting state networks (RSNs) are a set of anatomically contiguous brain regions that are functionally connected in a coherent manner. RSNs have been identified by functional MRI, but their functional significance is still unclear. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest and activated during task performance. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results suggest that metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. Copyright © 2015. RNA modifications are important for gene regulation. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap in eukaryotes. We show that NAD-capped mRNAs are found in both the nucleus and mitochondria. NAD-capped mRNAs are produced cotranscriptionally. We also show that NAD-capped mRNAs are enriched in the nucleus and mitochondria. These results suggest that NAD-capped mRNAs are important for gene regulation in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that DNA methylation at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes from people with diabetes are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease with high morbidity and mortality. The mechanisms underlying the development of alcohol dependence are not fully understood. In this study, we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Moreover, we found that gut leakiness is associated with altered gut microbiota composition and activity. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tomato fruit are a major source of food flavor, and the quality of the flavor is determined by the composition of the volatile chemicals. The biosynthesis of these volatile chemicals is poorly understood, and the only known nitrogenous volatiles are produced in tomato fruit. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce these compounds. This pathway is unique among known nitrogenous volatile biosynthetic pathways in plants. The identification of this pathway will enable the development of tomato cultivars with improved flavor. Global warming and biodiversity loss are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these threats are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of biodiversity conservation and climate change mitigation policies. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It contains two subregions, the superficial layer (MECs) and the deep layer (parasubiculum). The organization of neurons in these two subregions is poorly understood. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to record from freely moving mice in an open field. We found that neurons in the superficial layer of MECs form clusters that are topographically organized. Grid cells, which are thought to be essential for navigation, are topographically organized and form clusters that are distinct from those of other neurons. These data provide a framework for understanding the organization of neurons in MECs and their role in navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Dodder is a root- and leafless parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. This study shows that the flowering signal FT is required for host flowering and that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host. This may allow the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here we show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected? We conducted a large-scale study to understand how people feel connected to others. We found that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected people feel. People feel more connected to others who respond quickly to them than to others who respond quickly to others. People also use this signal to evaluate the connection between themselves and third-party listeners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are responsible for generating the heart rate and are therefore critical for maintaining cardiac function. SAN dysfunction is a hallmark of many heart diseases. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, which we call sinoatrial cells (SANCs). We demonstrate that SANCs are responsible for the generation of the SAN pacemaker activity. We also show that STIM1 regulates SAN function by controlling the content of intracellular Ca2+ stores and the electrical properties of the plasma membrane. Our findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for treating heart diseases. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice. We demonstrate that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism and suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver siRNA to plants and that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for plant cell internalization and gene silencing. This work also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. Eutrophication of nearshore ecosystems is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal waters worldwide. However, the role of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient inputs is poorly understood. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. Our results reveal that small watersheds can be important sources of coastal nutrients. Although they represent only a modest proportion of lake-wide loads, expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our findings highlight the need to consider the role of small watersheds in coastal nutrient loading. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems. We also find that the network dynamics can be accelerated by the addition of noise. This finding is relevant to the study of stochastic dynamics in chemical systems.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis causes changes in the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex that can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We use a dynamic causal model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that these changes render microcircuitry susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. The history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that this event was associated with an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean. This study provides insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the role of organic matter in triggering these events. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation. Certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate and government commitments to reduce this deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Certification lowered deforestation by 33% from a counterfactual of 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certified areas held less than 1% of forests remaining within oil palm plantations in 2015. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for reducing deforestation. Rather, it is a tool that can be used in combination with other strategies. The exocyst complex is a large protein complex involved in the final steps of exocytosis. Dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases. However, the study of the exocyst complex is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes in human and plant models. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This article is protected by copyright. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In contrast, in many fish, birds, and insects, sex is determined by multiple interacting alleles. Here we show that the multiple alleles of sex determination in cichlids can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics. This modular variation can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The retina is challenged by multiple reactive species that can damage photoreceptor cells. We sought to understand how iron levels impact the retina. We found that iron levels in retinal pigment epithelial cells, which are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids, are important for photoreceptor cell survival. We also found that iron levels can promote the photooxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration. Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use specialized tentacle structures armed with nematocysts for prey capture. These tentacles are highly diverse, and are used by siphonophores to capture a wide range of prey. We studied siphonophore tentacles from 45 species, and found that siphonophore specialization can evolve from one prey type to another. We also found that siphonophore nematocysts are highly specialized for their prey type, and that nematocyst evolution is linked to the evolution of tentacle morphology. Our findings suggest that siphonophore specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological innovations, and that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentacles and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The fossil record shows that the human hand evolved over a long period of time, with the most derived features appearing in the Middle Pleistocene and the most primitive features appearing in the earliest hominins. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units. We report the discovery of small-molecule dual inhibitors of human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1/2 (SHMT1/2). These compounds are effective in cancer cell lines and xenograft models of colon cancer. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is increasingly being recognized. However, the causal effects of deforestation on people’s diets have not been studied. We show that deforestation in rural Tanzania led to a reduction in people’s fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of their diets. Conversely, we found that forest fragmentation led to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production and economic growth. However, the expansion of mechanization has come at the cost of soil degradation. We show that the increase in farm vehicle weight has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers. This has resulted in a global map of subsoil compaction susceptibility, with 20% of arable land at risk. We hypothesize that the development of subsoil compaction is a recent phenomenon, and that the large sauropods roaming the Earth millions of years ago would have caused similar damage to the soil. This suggests that the ecological strategies of these giants may have included the development of fixed foraging trails.
